doc.line: This properties provides the actual position and the source of the position data. If source is "invalid" don't use the position information. The update frequency is at least 1Hz.
the latitude of the position in degree.
the longitude of the position in degree.
source/quality of position information.
country code of current position.
source/validity of country code information.
timezone of current position.
out -> i32TimeZoneDifference : difference in seconds to UTC
out -> u8DST_State: state of daylight saving time.
out -> i32DSTDifference: difference in seconds to 'normal' time when daylight saving time is in effect.
source/validity of time zone information.

This property provides information about the actual velocity and the source of the velocity value. If the source is "invalid" don't use the velocity. When the speed value is not calibrated in an environment where calibration is expected e.g. in a device with navigation and dead reckoning, the status will be invalid until a valid calibration is available. The update frequency is at least 1Hz.
velocity in [km/h].
source/quality of velocity information.
This property provides the current deadreckoning information. If source is "invalid" don't use the deadreckoning information. The update frequency is at least 1Hz.

arg.name: drTimestamp
arg.doc: Timestamp of deadreckoning information since the Epoch (00:00:00 UTC, January 1, 1970), measured in milliseconds.

arg.name: drSystemTime
arg.doc: SystemTime of used sensors. Unit (tics since systemstart) depends on platform.

arg.name: drLatitude
arg.doc: The WGS84-latitude of the deadreckoning position in degree

arg.name: drLongitude
arg.doc: The WGS84-longitude of the deadreckoning position in degree

doc.line: The deadreckoning heading (orientation of the car). Clockwise in degree.
North is at 0 degree, East is at 90 degree, South is at 180 degree, West is at 270 degree.

arg.name: drSpeed
arg.doc: The deadreckoning speed [m/s]. Value is negative if car drives backwards.

arg.name: drAltitude
arg.doc: The altitude of the deadreckoning position related to mean sea level [m].

doc.line: The deadreckoning turnrate around X-Axis.
X-Axis is pointing from back to front of the vehicle (Longitudinal Axis or Roll Axis).
Positive value means the left side of the vehicle is raised, while the right side is lowered [ degree/s].
The deadreckoning turnrate around Y-Axis.
Y-Axis is pointing from right to left side of the vehicle (Lateral Axis or Pitch Axis).
Positive value means the front of the vehicle is lowered, while the back is raised [ degree/s].
The deadreckoning turnrate around Z-Axis.
Z-Axis is pointing from the floor to the roof of the vehicle (Normal Axis or Yaw Axis).
Positive value means the front of the vehicle is turned to the left [ degree/s].
The deadreckoning acceleration along X-Axis.
X-Axis is pointing from back to front of the vehicle (Longitudinal Axis).
Positive value means the vehicle is accelerated in forward direction [m/ss].
The deadreckoning acceleration along Y-Axis.
Y-Axis is pointing from right to left side of the vehicle (Lateral Axis).
Positive value means the vehicle is accelerated to the left [m/ss].
E.g. when driving a curve to the left, the accelerometer measures the centripetal force as positive value.
The deadreckoning acceleration along Z-Axis.
Z-Axis is pointing from floor to the roof of the vehicle (Normal Axis).
Positive value means the vehicle is accelerated up [m/ss].
Keep in mind, that g-force is completely included in the measured value with ~ +9.8m/ss, when vehicle is horizontally aligned.
